conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball at point B.
The ball has a charge +q, and there are two fixed point charges, +Q at point M and -Q at point N.
Points M, N, and B form an equilateral triangle with side length L.
The line MN passes through point C and is perpendicular to BCD.
The ball is released from point A and moves along the tube to point B.
The electric force on the ball at point B is due to the charges at M and N.
Calculate the force exerted by each charge on the ball and find the resultant force.
Distance from B to M and B to N is L.
Force exerted by the charge at M on the ball is F_{BM} = k * q * Q / L^2.
Force exerted by the charge at N on the ball is F_{BN} = k * q * Q / L^2.
Angle between MB and NB is 60 degrees.
Forces F_{BM} and F_{BN} are equal in magnitude and symmetrically placed.
Resultant force F_R can be found using vector addition: F_R = sqrt(F_{BM}^2 + F_{BN}^2 + 2 * F_{BM} * F_{BN} * cos(60 degrees)).
Substituting the values, F_R = sqrt((k * q * Q / L^2)^2 + (k * q * Q / L^2)^2 + 2 * (k * q * Q / L^2) * (k * q * Q / L^2) * 1/2).
Simplifying, F_R = sqrt(2 * (k * q * Q / L^2)^2 + (k * q * Q / L^2)^2).
F_R = sqrt(3) * k * q * Q / L^2.
The magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball when it reaches point B is F_R = sqrt(3) * k * q * Q / L^2.
